articles.headline: Facebook and Twitter Say China Is Spreading Disinformation in Hong Kong
articles.snippet: The social media companies removed accounts and said they were sowing divisive messages about the Hong Kong protests.
articles.abstract: The social media companies removed accounts and said they were sowing divisive messages about the Hong Kong protests.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — China has adopted Russia’s playbook for spreading disinformation on Facebook and Twitter, deploying those tactics in its increasingly heated information war over the protests that have convulsed Hong Kong.

articles.headline: ISIS Is Regaining Strength in Iraq and Syria
articles.snippet: Five months after its territorial defeat, the Islamic State is conducting guerrilla attacks as defense officials acknowledge that the terrorist group is here to stay.
articles.abstract: Five months after its territorial defeat, the Islamic State is conducting guerrilla attacks as defense officials acknowledge that the terrorist group is here to stay.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Five months after American-backed forces ousted the Islamic State from its last shard of territory in Syria, the terrorist group is gathering new strength, conducting guerrilla attacks across Iraq and Syria, retooling its financial networks and targeting new recruits at an allied-run tent camp, American and Iraqi military and intelligence officers said.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt, Alissa J. Rubin and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

articles.headline: Trump Administration Considers Moves to Bolster Economy
articles.snippet: Options could include a payroll tax cut or reversing tariffs.
articles.abstract: Options could include a payroll tax cut or reversing tariffs.
articles.lead_paragraph: White House officials have begun preparing options to help bolster the American economy and prevent it from falling into a recession, including mulling a potential payroll tax cut and a possible reversal of some of President Trump’s tariffs, according to people familiar with the discussions.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Jim Tankersley and Annie Karni

articles.headline: State Attorneys General Said to Be Near Formal Investigation of Tech Companies
articles.snippet: Their bipartisan effort comes after a smaller group of the state representatives met last month with antitrust officials at the Justice Department.
articles.abstract: Their bipartisan effort comes after a smaller group of the state representatives met last month with antitrust officials at the Justice Department.
articles.lead_paragraph: The state attorneys general in more than a dozen states are preparing to begin an antitrust investigation of the tech giants, according to two people briefed on the discussions, increasing pressure on the companies.

articles.headline: How Shareholder Democracy Failed the People
articles.snippet: Shareholder democracy seemed like a good idea at the time. What we got was shareholder supremacy.
articles.abstract: Shareholder democracy seemed like a good idea at the time. What we got was shareholder supremacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Democracy is a messy thing. Shareholder democracy may be even messier.

articles.headline: Banks Want Efficiency. Critics Warn of Backsliding.
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve is streamlining postcrisis bank regulation. The end result could be lower capital requirements for the biggest banks.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve is streamlining postcrisis bank regulation. The end result could be lower capital requirements for the biggest banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A decade after big banks needed government support to dig out of the financial crisis, the Federal Reserve is slowly, but steadily, making a series of regulatory changes that could chip away at new requirements put in place to prevent a repeat of the 2008 meltdown.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek, Peter Eavis and Emily Flitter

articles.headline: What ‘Victory’ Looks Like: A Journey Through Shattered Syria
articles.snippet: On an eight-day visit,  New York Times journalists given rare access to Syria found ruin, grief and generosity. What was missing after eight years of civil war? Young men and a middle class.
articles.abstract: On an eight-day visit,  New York Times journalists given rare access to Syria found ruin, grief and generosity. What was missing after eight years of civil war? Young men and a middle class.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOUMA, Syria — Picking our way around the ruins of the Damascus suburb of Douma, it took a little while to realize what was missing.
articles.byline: By Vivian Yee and Meridith Kohut

articles.headline: China’s Soft-Power Failure: Condemning Hong Kong’s Protests
articles.snippet: Beijing wants greater sway over global public opinion. Instead, its propaganda outlets make Chinese leaders look like bullies.
articles.abstract: Beijing wants greater sway over global public opinion. Instead, its propaganda outlets make Chinese leaders look like bullies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Images of masked thugs massing in Hong Kong’s streets. Unproven allegations that protesters are being led by the C.I.A. Comparisons between activists and Nazis.

articles.headline: Italy’s Government Collapses, Turning Chaos Into Crisis
articles.snippet: A power play by the popular interior minister, Matteo Salvini, imploded the coalition. But for now, the election he wants remains just out of reach.
articles.abstract: A power play by the popular interior minister, Matteo Salvini, imploded the coalition. But for now, the election he wants remains just out of reach.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — After 14 months of bickering, Italy’s government collapsed on Tuesday, plunging a key European nation already hobbled by financial fragility and political chaos into a renewed period of crisis and uncertainty.

articles.headline: Welcome to McDonald’s. Would You Like a Podcast With That?
articles.snippet: With podcasts rising in popularity, it’s no surprise that companies are producing their own. What’s more surprising is that people are actually listening to them.
articles.abstract: With podcasts rising in popularity, it’s no surprise that companies are producing their own. What’s more surprising is that people are actually listening to them.
articles.lead_paragraph: The hit podcast “Serial” was the audio investigation that launched a thousand true-crime dramas, inspiring podcasters across the country to attempt ambitious reporting projects with gritty subject matter. There were “Dirty John” and “Hollywood & Crime,” “Death in Ice Valley” and “Atlanta Monster.”
